    • Method Detail

      • main

        public static void main​(String[] args)

      • demoSynchronized

        public static void demoSynchronized()
        Synchronized keyboard denote memory-barrier crossing and thread locking for a block of code In this demo, two synchronized methods in two independent threads are changing the same instance value, {code syncCounter}, they are blocking each other since they share the same lock monitor, the host instance. This mutual blocking between threads by synchronization is a big impact to performance.

      • syncIncreaseCounter

        protected void syncIncreaseCounter()
        synchronize on instance, delay some time and then change counter value

      • syncDecreaseCounter

        protected void syncDecreaseCounter()
        synchronize on instance, delay some time and then change counter value

      • demoVolatile

        public static void demoVolatile()
        A volatile variable has read/write directly from/to the main memory for all threads. There's no explicit synchronization needed on a volatile variable to cross memory barrier. In this demo, any change on the volaCounter variable is instantly seen by all threads. Due to interleaving read/write from ADD and SUB threads, the before and after value is not consistently the result of +1/-1 logic within ADD or SUB thread.
